title: Ezekiel Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 22.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 22:2, what is the 'bloody city' that the son of man is asked to judge?
questions.correctAnswer: The city shedding blood
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:2 refers to the 'bloody city' as the one the son of man is commanded to judge and show her abominations, indicating a city shedding blood.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 22:3, what two sins are attributed to the city?
questions.correctAnswer: Shedding blood and making idols
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states the city 'sheddeth blood in the midst of it' and 'maketh idols against herself to defile herself.'

questions.question: What consequence does Ezekiel 22:4 say will happen because of the city's guilt?
options: Made a reproach to the heathen
questions.correctAnswer: Made a reproach to the heathen
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:4 says that because of the city's guilt, it is made 'a reproach unto the heathen, and a mocking to all countries.'

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 22:6, who were involved in shedding blood in the city?
questions.correctAnswer: Princes of Israel
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states 'the princes of Israel, every one were in thee to their power to shed blood.'

questions.question: Ezekiel 22:7 mentions mistreatment of certain groups. Which groups are these?
options: Father and mother, stranger, fatherless and widow
questions.correctAnswer: Father and mother, stranger, fatherless and widow
questions.explanation: Verse 7 says they 'set light by father and mother,' oppressed the stranger, and vexed the fatherless and widow.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 22:8 states that the city honored God's holy things and kept the sabbaths.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:8 clearly states the city 'hast despised mine holy things, and hast profaned my sabbaths,' showing disrespect rather than honor.

questions.question: What sinful acts are described in Ezekiel 22:9?
options: Carrying tales to shed blood, eating upon mountains, committing lewdness
questions.correctAnswer: Carrying tales to shed blood, eating upon mountains, committing lewdness
questions.explanation: Verse 9 describes men carrying tales to shed blood, eating upon mountains, and committing lewdness in the city.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 22:11, what kinds of immoral behavior are mentioned?
options: Abomination with neighbor's wife, defiling daughter-in-law, humiliating sister
questions.correctAnswer: Abomination with neighbor's wife, defiling daughter-in-law, humiliating sister
questions.explanation: Verse 11 lists these specific immoral acts: one committing abomination with neighbor's wife, another defiling his daughter-in-law, and another humiliating his sister.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 22:12 says, 'In thee have they taken gifts to shed blood; thou hast taken usury and increase, and thou hast greedily gained of thy neighbours by ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: extortion
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states they have 'greedily gained of thy neighbours by extortion.'

questions.question: What punishment does God declare in Ezekiel 22:15 for the city's filthiness?
options: Scatter among the heathen and consume filthiness
questions.correctAnswer: Scatter among the heathen and consume filthiness
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states God will 'scatter thee among the heathen, and disperse thee in the countries, and will consume thy filthiness out of thee.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 22:18, the house of Israel is like valuable pure silver to the Lord.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 18 describes Israel as 'dross' and the dross of silver, indicating impurity rather than pure silver.

questions.question: What simile does Ezekiel 22:20 use to describe God's gathering of Israel in anger?
options: Gathering metals into a furnace to melt
questions.correctAnswer: Gathering metals into a furnace to melt
questions.explanation: Verse 20 compares God's gathering to melting silver, brass, iron, lead, and tin in the furnace.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 22:25, what have the prophets done in the land?
options: Conspired, devoured souls, taken treasures, made widows
Healed the sick and helped poor
questions.correctAnswer: Conspired, devoured souls, taken treasures, made widows
questions.explanation: Verse 25 describes a conspiracy of prophets who devour souls, take treasures, and cause many widows.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 22:30 says God found a man to stand in the gap and save the land from destruction.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 30 states God sought a man to stand in the gap but found none.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Ezekiel 22:31 for God's indignation and wrath upon the people?
options: Because of their own way recompensed upon their heads
questions.correctAnswer: Because of their own way recompensed upon their heads
questions.explanation: Verse 31 declares God poured out indignation and wrath, recompensing them for their own ways.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with guilt over past sins and asks for guidance. Based on Ezekiel 22, what biblical truth would you share about acknowledging sin and its consequences?
options: Confess your sins and understand that God’s judgment is just and will come upon unrepentant sin.
Ignore your guilt because God always forgives without any consequences.
Only worry about sins that others see, not the ones in your heart.
Avoid thinking about your sins to keep peace of mind.
questions.correctAnswer: Confess your sins and understand that God’s judgment is just and will come upon unrepentant sin.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:3-4, 13-14 show that the city is guilty of bloodshed and idolatry and that God will deal justly with sin. Acknowledging sin is important because God’s judgment will come upon those who persist in wickedness.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 22 teach us about integrity in daily life when dealing with others?
options: One must avoid extortion and dishonest gain, remembering God’s displeasure against such acts.
It is acceptable to exploit others if it benefits you.
Integrity is optional if no one finds out about wrongdoing.
Only leaders need to be honest, not ordinary people.
questions.correctAnswer: One must avoid extortion and dishonest gain, remembering God’s displeasure against such acts.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:12-13 condemns taking gifts to shed blood and gaining greedily by extortion, showing God's anger toward dishonest gain and emphasizing integrity.

questions.question: A believer asks how to persevere through trials of injustice and oppression. What biblical encouragement does Ezekiel 22 provide?
options: God sees all injustice and will bring righteous judgment and purification in His time.
One must avenge wrongs immediately without waiting on God.
Ignore injustice as it is part of life and will never be resolved.
Suffer silently and do not expect God to act.
questions.correctAnswer: God sees all injustice and will bring righteous judgment and purification in His time.
questions.explanation: Verses like Ezekiel 22:15-16 and 20-22 reveal God's promise to scatter the wicked and melt them in His anger, assuring believers that God’s justice will prevail.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 22 teach about the role of spiritual leaders in fostering holiness and obedience?
options: Spiritual leaders must uphold God’s law and distinguish between holy and profane, or face God’s judgment.
Leaders can ignore God’s law if it suits their purposes.
Prophets may teach lies if it comforts the people.
Priests should focus only on rituals and not moral behavior.
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual leaders must uphold God’s law and distinguish between holy and profane, or face God’s judgment.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:26-28 condemns priests and prophets who profaned holy things and taught lies, emphasizing the responsibility of leaders to teach truth and holiness.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 22 emphasize the importance of intercessory prayer and standing in the gap for others?
options: God sought a man to stand in the gap to prevent destruction but found none, highlighting the need for intercessors.
Intercessory prayer is unnecessary because God acts alone.
Only kings should pray for the people, not ordinary believers.
Standing in the gap means physically protecting people, not praying.
questions.correctAnswer: God sought a man to stand in the gap to prevent destruction but found none, highlighting the need for intercessors.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:30 shows God looking for a man to intercede and protect the land, underscoring the biblical value of intercessory prayer and spiritual responsibility for others.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 22, what is a biblical response when witnessing widespread corruption and sin in the community?
options: Pray earnestly for repentance and seek to live a holy life as a witness.
Join in the corruption since everyone is doing it.
Ignore the sin and focus only on personal salvation.
Rebel violently against the corrupt leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Pray earnestly for repentance and seek to live a holy life as a witness.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:18-22 portrays the people as dross in the furnace, but God's aim is purification. Believers are called to pray and live holy lives to reflect God’s standards.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 22 illustrate the consequences of neglecting God’s holy days and sacred things?
options: Ignoring the sabbaths and holy things leads to God’s reproach and judgment.
Holy days are optional and have no impact on one’s standing with God.
Profaning holy things brings blessings if done secretly.
Only priests are accountable for respecting holy things.
questions.correctAnswer: Ignoring the sabbaths and holy things leads to God’s reproach and judgment.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:8 and 26 state that profaning God’s sabbaths and holy things results in God being profaned among the people and brings judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 22 teaches that God’s anger will be poured out on those who practice oppression and dishonesty.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:29-31 clearly states that God poured out His indignation on those who oppressed the poor and practiced dishonesty, showing His righteous anger against sin.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 22, God will scatter the unrepentant among the nations as part of His judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:15 describes God scattering the people among the heathen and consuming their filthiness, demonstrating His judgment through dispersion.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 22 compares the house of Israel to ______, being dross in the furnace awaiting purification.
questions.correctAnswer: brass, tin, iron, and lead
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:18 uses the metals brass, tin, iron, and lead to describe Israel as dross, emphasizing their impurity and need for refinement through God's judgment.

questions.question: A believer faces temptation to oppress the vulnerable for personal gain. Based on Ezekiel 22, what biblical principle should guide their actions?
options: Respect the poor and strangers, avoiding oppression and robbery.
Use opportunities for gain even if it harms the needy.
Ignore the needs of others to focus on personal success.
Oppression is acceptable if it is hidden from others.
questions.correctAnswer: Respect the poor and strangers, avoiding oppression and robbery.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:7 and 29 condemn oppression of strangers, orphans, widows, and the poor, urging believers to act justly and with compassion.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 22 teach about humility and accountability before God in leadership?
options: Leaders who seek dishonest gain and shed blood will face God’s wrath and destruction.
Leaders are always excused from judgment because of their position.
Power allows leaders to ignore God’s laws without consequence.
Leaders should prioritize personal ambition over God’s commands.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders who seek dishonest gain and shed blood will face God’s wrath and destruction.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:6-7 and 27 indicate that princes who shed blood and seek dishonest gain are like wolves and will be judged by God, emphasizing accountability and humility.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 22 say about God’s knowledge and judgment of secret sins and abominations?
options: God is fully aware of all sins, including secret abominations, and will bring judgment accordingly.
Secret sins are hidden from God and do not matter.
Only public sins are judged by God.
God overlooks secret sins if the person repents publicly.
questions.correctAnswer: God is fully aware of all sins, including secret abominations, and will bring judgment accordingly.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:9-11 describes various secret sins like lewdness and abominations committed in the city, showing God’s awareness and impending judgment.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 22, what role does remembering God and His commandments play in avoiding greed and extortion?
options: Forgetting God leads to greed and extortion, while remembering Him fosters honesty and integrity.
Remembering God has no effect on business practices.
Greed and extortion are acceptable if God is remembered.
God only cares about worship, not daily conduct.
questions.correctAnswer: Forgetting God leads to greed and extortion, while remembering Him fosters honesty and integrity.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:12 states that people have forgotten God while greedily gaining by extortion, linking remembrance of God with ethical behavior.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 22 encourage believers to demonstrate faith through obedience and holiness in family life?
options: Avoid defiling family relationships and honor parents, reflecting God’s standards in the home.
Family sins are private and unimportant to God.
Obedience in family matters is optional for believers.
Only community behavior matters, not family conduct.
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid defiling family relationships and honor parents, reflecting God’s standards in the home.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:7 and 10-11 mention dishonoring father and mother and defiling family members as abominations, stressing the importance of holiness in family life.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 22.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 22, what imagery is used to describe the house of Israel's moral state in verse 18?
options: Dross in the midst of the furnace
questions.correctAnswer: Dross in the midst of the furnace
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:18 uses metallurgical imagery, describing Israel as dross (impurities) mixed with metals in a furnace, symbolizing their moral corruption and impurity.

questions.question: Which specific sins does Ezekiel accuse the princes of Israel of committing in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Shedding blood to their power
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:6 states the princes of Israel were involved in shedding blood to their power, highlighting their violence and injustice.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'to stand in the gap' in Ezekiel 22:30 refer to in a broader biblical context?
options: Interceding or praying to prevent judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Interceding or praying to prevent judgment
questions.explanation: The phrase 'stand in the gap' in Ezekiel 22:30 denotes intercession, a concept seen elsewhere in Scripture where a righteous person intervenes to avert divine judgment.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel describe the behavior of the prophets in Jerusalem in Ezekiel 22:25?
options: Like a roaring lion devouring prey
questions.correctAnswer: Like a roaring lion devouring prey
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:25 compares the prophets to a roaring lion, emphasizing their destructive and exploitative behavior rather than faithful leadership.

questions.question: What consequence does the LORD declare for the city in Ezekiel 22:15?
options: Scattering among the heathen and consumption of filthiness
Immediate destruction by fire without exile
questions.correctAnswer: Scattering among the heathen and consumption of filthiness
questions.explanation: In Ezekiel 22:15, God declares that He will scatter the city among the heathen and consume its impurity, symbolizing judgment and exile.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 22:12, what economic sins are highlighted as contributing to the city's guilt?
questions.correctAnswer: Usury, extortion, and dishonest gain
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:12 condemns the taking of gifts to shed blood, usury, increase, and greed through extortion, illustrating social injustice.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 22:20-22 to depict God's judgment?
options: Simile comparing Israel to metals melted in a furnace
questions.correctAnswer: Simile comparing Israel to metals melted in a furnace
questions.explanation: Verses 20-22 use a simile comparing Israel to metals melted in a furnace, illustrating purification through judgment, a common prophetic metaphor.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 22:26, the priests honored the distinction between holy and profane things.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:26 states that the priests put no difference between holy and profane, violating God's law and profaning holy things.

questions.question: What is the significance of the term 'son of man' as used repeatedly in Ezekiel 22?
options: It emphasizes Ezekiel's humanity and role as God's messenger
It denotes a divine status equal to God
It refers to the people of Israel collectively
It is a title for the king of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes Ezekiel's humanity and role as God's messenger
questions.explanation: 'Son of man' highlights Ezekiel's human nature and his prophetic calling to deliver God's message, consistent with its use throughout Ezekiel.

questions.question: Which social groups are specifically mentioned as being oppressed in Ezekiel 22?
questions.correctAnswer: Strangers, fatherless, and widows
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:7 references oppression of the stranger, fatherless, and widow, groups often vulnerable in ancient Near Eastern society.

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'Thus saith the Lord GOD' function as in the structure of Ezekiel 22?
options: A prophetic formula asserting divine authority
A call for the people to worship idols
questions.correctAnswer: A prophetic formula asserting divine authority
questions.explanation: The phrase 'Thus saith the Lord GOD' (e.g., Ezekiel 22:3, 19) serves as a prophetic formula to establish the authority of the message.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Ezekiel 22:31, God has poured out His indignation and consumed the people with the fire of His _____.
questions.correctAnswer: wrath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:31 states that God poured out His indignation and consumed them with the fire of His wrath, indicating judgment against their sins.

questions.question: How do the prophets in Ezekiel 22:28 deceive the people?
options: By divining lies and claiming 'Thus saith the Lord' when He has not spoken
questions.correctAnswer: By divining lies and claiming 'Thus saith the Lord' when He has not spoken
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:28 condemns prophets who falsely claim divine authority to spread vanity and lies, misleading the people.

questions.question: What does the metaphor of 'taking thine inheritance in thyself in the sight of the heathen' in Ezekiel 22:16 likely signify?
options: Experiencing shame and loss before the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Experiencing shame and loss before the nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:16 suggests that Israel will bear shame and loss of their inheritance openly before the nations as a result of judgment.

questions.question: What theme in Ezekiel 22 is echoed in the New Testament book of Revelation regarding judgment and purification?
options: The refining fire that purifies and judges the wicked
The establishment of a new temple
The end of all laws and commandments
questions.correctAnswer: The refining fire that purifies and judges the wicked
questions.explanation: The metaphor of refining fire in Ezekiel 22:20-22 parallels Revelation's depiction of divine judgment by fire purifying the earth (Revelation 20:9-10).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 22:2-4, what is Jerusalem accused of that brings God’s judgment upon it?
questions.correctAnswer: Shedding blood and making idols
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:2-4 states that the city sheds blood in its midst and makes idols to defile itself, leading to God's judgment. This theme is consistent with passages like Isaiah 1:15-17, Jeremiah 7:9-11, and Romans 1:18-23 which condemn idolatry and bloodshed as grounds for divine wrath.

questions.question: What is the role of the princes of Israel in the sins described in Ezekiel 22:6-7?
options: They shed blood and oppressed the fatherless and widow
They led the people in worship of the true God
They built altars to the Lord
They protected strangers and the poor
questions.correctAnswer: They shed blood and oppressed the fatherless and widow
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:6-7 highlights that the princes shed blood and oppressed vulnerable groups such as orphans and widows. This aligns with the prophetic critique of unjust leaders found in Micah 3:1-3 and James 5:1-6, emphasizing God's condemnation of corrupt leadership.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 22:8-9, what specific religious offenses does the city commit?
options: Despising holy things, profaning sabbaths, and committing lewdness
questions.correctAnswer: Despising holy things, profaning sabbaths, and committing lewdness
questions.explanation: The city is accused of despising God's holy things, profaning sabbaths, and committing lewdness (Ezekiel 22:8-9). This reflects Old Testament emphasis on holiness (Leviticus 19:30), Sabbath observance (Exodus 20:8-11), and sexual purity (Leviticus 18), consistent with New Testament teaching on holiness (Hebrews 10:26-31; 1 Thessalonians 4:3-7).

questions.question: Which of the following sins is NOT explicitly listed in Ezekiel 22:10-11?
options: Committing abomination with a neighbor's wife
questions.correctAnswer: Offering false sacrifices
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:10-11 details sexual sins including incest and adultery, but does not mention offering false sacrifices, which is addressed elsewhere (e.g., Malachi 1:7-8). These sins violate God's holiness and covenant laws (Leviticus 18; Deuteronomy 22) and are condemned in both Old and New Testaments (1 Corinthians 6:9-10).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 22:12 accuse the people of doing in relation to bloodshed and economic practices?
options: Taking bribes to shed blood and practicing usury and extortion
Forgiving debts and helping the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Taking bribes to shed blood and practicing usury and extortion
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:12 condemns taking bribes to shed blood, usury, and extortion, reflecting injustice and greed. This is consistent with biblical teachings against corrupt economic practices (Exodus 22:25; Proverbs 28:8; Luke 3:13-14) and emphasizes God's concern for justice and mercy (Micah 6:8).

questions.question: What consequence does God pronounce in Ezekiel 22:15-16 for the city's filthiness and sins?
options: Scatter the people among the nations and consume their filthiness
Bless the city and make it prosperous
Build a new temple for them
questions.correctAnswer: Scatter the people among the nations and consume their filthiness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:15-16 declares that God will scatter the people among the nations and consume their filthiness, indicating exile as judgment for sin. This aligns with Deuteronomy 28:64 and Babylonian exile narratives (2 Kings 24-25), illustrating God's holiness and justice in punishing unrepentant sin.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 22:18-22, Israel is compared to dross in a furnace. What theological truth does this metaphor convey?
options: God’s refining judgment will purify Israel through suffering
Israel is eternally condemned with no hope
Israel is exalted above all nations
Israel’s sins are forgiven without consequence
questions.correctAnswer: God’s refining judgment will purify Israel through suffering
questions.explanation: The dross metaphor in Ezekiel 22:18-22 illustrates God's refining judgment to purify Israel. This reflects the biblical motif of God as refiner (Malachi 3:2-3), purifying his people through trials (Isaiah 48:10; 1 Peter 1:6-7), underscoring both divine holiness and mercy.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Thou art the land that is not cleansed, nor rained upon in the day of indignation' in Ezekiel 22:24?
options: It symbolizes judgment without relief or cleansing
It means the land will prosper abundantly
It refers to a drought caused by natural disaster
It predicts immediate restoration and blessing
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes judgment without relief or cleansing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:24 uses this phrase to signify severe judgment without mercy or cleansing. This imagery aligns with prophetic warnings of divine wrath (Jeremiah 14:1-6; Hosea 6:1-3) showing that God’s indignation leads to desolation if there is no repentance.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 22:25-27 describe the conduct of prophets, priests, and princes in Jerusalem?
options: They conspire, violate God's law, and act like wolves seeking dishonest gain
They lead the people in righteousness and truth
They build the temple and teach the law faithfully
They repent and seek God's mercy
questions.correctAnswer: They conspire, violate God's law, and act like wolves seeking dishonest gain
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:25-27 condemns the prophets, priests, and princes for conspiracies, law violations, and predatory behavior. This corrupt leadership theme occurs elsewhere (Micah 3:1-4; Jeremiah 5:30-31; Matthew 23) and demonstrates God's intolerance of covenant unfaithfulness and injustice.

questions.question: What false practice do the prophets engage in according to Ezekiel 22:28?
options: Divining lies and saying 'Thus saith the Lord' without God's word
questions.correctAnswer: Divining lies and saying 'Thus saith the Lord' without God's word
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:28 accuses prophets of speaking lies and falsely claiming divine authority, a serious offense condemned in Deuteronomy 18:20-22 and Jeremiah 14:14. This highlights the importance of true prophecy and accountability before God.

questions.question: What social sins are the people of the land guilty of in Ezekiel 22:29?
options: Oppression, robbery, vexing the poor and needy, and wrongful oppression of strangers
Sharing wealth and caring for the poor
questions.correctAnswer: Oppression, robbery, vexing the poor and needy, and wrongful oppression of strangers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:29 lists social sins including oppression and robbery, particularly of vulnerable groups. This condemnation aligns with biblical calls to justice and care for the marginalized (Isaiah 1:17; James 1:27; Proverbs 14:31).

questions.question: What was God seeking among the people in Ezekiel 22:30, and what was the result?
options: A man to stand in the gap and make up the hedge, but none was found
A prophet to lead a rebellion, but many were found
A priest to offer sacrifices, and several were found
A king to rule justly, and one was found
questions.correctAnswer: A man to stand in the gap and make up the hedge, but none was found
questions.explanation: God sought a mediator to intercede and protect the land (Ezekiel 22:30), but none was found. This highlights the absence of righteous leadership and intercession, paralleling Moses’ intercession (Exodus 32:11-14) and Christ as the ultimate mediator (1 Timothy 2:5).

questions.question: Ezekiel 22:31 describes God’s response to the persistent sin of the people. What is His response?
options: Pouring out indignation and consuming them with the fire of His wrath
questions.correctAnswer: Pouring out indignation and consuming them with the fire of His wrath
questions.explanation: God’s response to persistent sin is wrath and judgment (Ezekiel 22:31), consistent with the biblical doctrine of divine justice (Romans 1:18; Hebrews 10:26-31). This underscores God’s holiness and the seriousness of sin.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 22 emphasize the holiness of God in relation to the profanation of sabbaths and holy things (verses 8 and 26)?
options: God is profaned among them because they show no distinction between holy and profane
God accepts their offerings despite their sins
God ignores their failures to keep holy things
God rewards their efforts to worship in their own way
questions.correctAnswer: God is profaned among them because they show no distinction between holy and profane
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:8 and 26 reveal that when God's holy things and sabbaths are profaned and distinctions between holy and profane are ignored, God’s holiness is dishonored. This affirms the biblical teaching that God is holy and requires holiness from His people (Leviticus 19:2; 1 Peter 1:15-16).

questions.question: What does the scattering of the people among the nations (Ezekiel 22:15,19) signify theologically in the biblical narrative?
options: Divine judgment and exile as consequences of covenant unfaithfulness
God’s abandonment of His covenant people permanently
A reward for their military strength
A sign of God’s favor and blessing
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment and exile as consequences of covenant unfaithfulness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 22:15 and 19 indicate scattering as judgment for covenant unfaithfulness, echoing Deuteronomy 28 and exile narratives (2 Kings 24-25). This reflects God’s justice and the ongoing biblical theme that disobedience leads to consequences, yet restoration remains possible (Jeremiah 29:10-14).
